p: Phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) is usually the second most abundant phospholipid in animal and plant lipids [ 37]. The PE values were 164.33 mg/100g in seed and 56.74 mg/100g in pulp samples. In animal tissues, phosphatidylethanolamine is especially important in the sarcolemmal membranes of the heart during ischemia, it is involved in secretion of the nascent very-low-density lipoproteins from liver and it has functions in membrane fusion and fission. It also has a functional role in the Ca 2+- ATPase in that one molecule of PE is bound in a cavity between two transâ€“membrane helices, acting as a wedge to keep them apart. This is displaced when Ca 2+ is bound to the enzyme [ 38]
